comment._content: Hmm -- according to this contemporary news report, there was a huge earthquake in Mexico two days earlier that caused pronounced shocks 2700 miles away in DC, so perhaps that's what this is about.

comment._content: I like the old things :) It's very antique.

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: A big blizzard struck the whole east coast on March 2, 1914. news.google.com/newspapers?id=4rIyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8lMDA... That's probably what caused the damage.

comment.author: 9746548@N07
comment._content: Its remind me the piece from gordon Matta Clark : Bingo [http://www.flickr.com/photos/drumzofthesouth/3540799284/]

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: j3net: I think you are correct that this image shows buildings damaged by the strong winds during the blizzard of March 2, 1914. A Washington Post article of March 3, 1914 describes shattered windows, blown off roofs and other destruction of property. We will add to the record when we update the database.
